docs.title: Welcome to geolens
docs.text:
A python package for interactive mapping.

  • Free software: MIT license
  • Documentation: https://geonextgis.github.io/geolens

docs.title: Credits
docs.text: This package was created with Cookiecutter and the giswqs/pypackage project template.

docs.title: Contributing
docs.text:
Contributions are welcome, and they are greatly appreciated! Every little bit helps, and credit will always be given.

You can contribute in many ways:

docs.title: Report Bugs
docs.text:
Report bugs at https://github.com/geonextgis/geolens/issues.

If you are reporting a bug, please include:

  • Your operating system name and version.
  • Any details about your local setup that might be helpful in troubleshooting.
  • Detailed steps to reproduce the bug.

docs.title: Fix Bugs
docs.text: Look through the GitHub issues for bugs. Anything tagged with bug and help wanted is open to whoever wants to implement it.

docs.title: Implement Features
docs.text: Look through the GitHub issues for features. Anything tagged with enhancement and help wanted is open to whoever wants to implement it.

docs.title: Write Documentation
docs.text: geolens could always use more documentation, whether as part of the official geolens docs, in docstrings, or even on the web in blog posts, articles, and such.

docs.title: Submit Feedback
docs.text:
The best way to send feedback is to file an issue at https://github.com/geonextgis/geolens/issues.

If you are proposing a feature:

  • Explain in detail how it would work.
  • Keep the scope as narrow as possible, to make it easier to implement.
  • Remember that this is a volunteer-driven project, and that contributions are welcome :)

docs.title: Get Started!
docs.text:
Ready to contribute? Here's how to set up geolens for local development.

  1. Fork the geolens repo on GitHub.

  2. Clone your fork locally:

    $ git clone git@github.com:your_name_here/geolens.git

  3. Install your local copy into a virtualenv. Assuming you have virtualenvwrapper installed, this is how you set up your fork for local development:

    $ mkvirtualenv geolens
$ cd geolens/
$ python setup.py develop

  4. Create a branch for local development:

    $ git checkout -b name-of-your-bugfix-or-feature

    Now you can make your changes locally.

  5. When you're done making changes, check that your changes pass flake8 and the tests, including testing other Python versions with tox:

    $ flake8 geolens tests
$ python setup.py test or pytest
$ tox

    To get flake8 and tox, just pip install them into your virtualenv.

  6. Commit your changes and push your branch to GitHub:

    $ git add .
$ git commit -m "Your detailed description of your changes."
$ git push origin name-of-your-bugfix-or-feature

  7. Submit a pull request through the GitHub website.

docs.title: Pull Request Guidelines
docs.text:
Before you submit a pull request, check that it meets these guidelines:

  1. The pull request should include tests.
  2. If the pull request adds functionality, the docs should be updated. Put your new functionality into a function with a docstring, and add the feature to the list in README.rst.
  3. The pull request should work for Python 3.5, 3.6, 3.7 and 3.8, and for PyPy. Check https://github.com/geonextgis/geolens/pull_requests and make sure that the tests pass for all supported Python versions.

docs.title: generate_lucky_number(length=1)
docs.text:
Generates a random number of given length.

Parameters:

Name Type Description Default length int

The length of the number to generate. Defaults to 1.

1

Returns:

Type Description int

The generated number.

Source code in geolens/geolens.py 
def generate_lucky_number(length=1):
"""Generates a random number of given length.

    Args:
        length (int, optional): The length of the number to generate. Defaults to 1.

    Returns:
        int: The generated number.
    """
    digit = string.digits
    lucky_number = "".join(random.choice(digit) for i in range(length))
    return int(lucky_number)

docs.title: generate_random_password(length=10, upper=False, digits=False, punctuation=False)
docs.text:
Generates a random password of a given length.

Parameters:

Name Type Description Default length int

The length of the string to generate. Defaults to 10.

10 upper bool

Whether to include uppercase letters. Defaults to False.

False digits bool

Whether to include digits. Defaults to False.

False punctuation bool

Whether to include punctuation. Defaults to False.

False

Returns:

Type Description str

The generated password.

Source code in geolens/geolens.py 
def generate_random_password(length=10, upper=False, digits=False, punctuation=False):
"""Generates a random password of a given length.

    Args:
        length (int, optional): The length of the string to generate. Defaults to 10.
        upper (bool, optional): Whether to include uppercase letters. Defaults to False.
        digits (bool, optional): Whether to include digits. Defaults to False.
        punctuation (bool, optional): Whether to include punctuation. Defaults to False.

    Returns:
        str: The generated password.
    """
    letters = string.ascii_lowercase
    if upper:
        letters += string.ascii_uppercase
    if digits:
        letters += string.digits
    if punctuation:
        letters += string.punctuation
    password = "".join(random.choice(letters) for i in range(length))
    return password

docs.title: Stable release
docs.text:
To install geolens, run this command in your terminal:

pip install geolens

This is the preferred method to install geolens, as it will always install the most recent stable release.

If you don't have pip installed, this Python installation guide can guide you through the process.

docs.title: From sources
docs.text:
The sources for geolens can be downloaded from the Github repo.

You can clone the public repository:

git clone git://github.com/geonextgis/geolens

docs.title: Usage
docs.text:
To use geolens in a project:

import geolens

docs.text:
